bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Carlos E. Finlay, August 14, 1941

div1.p: Hench responds to Carlos E. Finlay's criticism of Cornwell's "Conquerors of Yellow Fever" painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Carlos E. Finlay, August 14, 1941
div1.p:
I appreciate your frank letter of August 6. I am sorry that
you feel that Mr. Cornwell did not get a good likeness of your father,
particularly because of the fact that he is one of the two most import-
ant figures in the painting.

We, of course, know that the painting is not literally correct
from the historical standpoint but we felt that no picture which pre-
sented a photographic and literal representation of any one incident in
the yellow fever story could possibly tell anything like the whole truth.

For example, the inoculation of Carroll's arm which took place
in a small laboratory could not be depicted in that little building in-
asmuch as so few persons could be placed in the painting. Reed, of course,
was not present, but certainly he was present in spirit. The scene which
we originally conceived--that of your father presenting the mosquitos'
eggs to the Yellow Fever Commission would leave out Major-General Wood.
As we now understand it, Wood's cooperation in getting the money and allow-
ing the experiments on human beings to take place was of primary importance

Then again, the original conception would have left out any credit
due to the soldiers who heroically submitted themselves for experimentation,
the most outstanding of which were Kissinger and Moran.

In other words, Dr. Finlay, we feel that this painting is more true
to the spirit of the Yellow Fever Investigation than any literal picture
might have been. It is an arrangement of portraits commemorative of as
many of the people involved as could be used with a maximum of artistic
license. Some of our critics have suggested several names that might well
have been included except that there was a limit to the number that could
be artistically handled in the composition of the painting.
